subject: RE: [junit] random testing with JUnit
msgSnippet: ... cases. ... point ... If you trust your eyes more than computers, you are probably in the wrong industry :-) ... Heavy doses of alcohol do wonder for me :-)
messageBody:
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Erik Neumann

> I confess that I have some System.out.println() statements in my test
cases.
> Partly it is to see which random cases were generated, and I see the
point
> that I shouldn't have to scan the output. However, at least I'm sure the
> tests are running the way I think they should be running!
> I distrust computers and software greatly

If you trust your eyes more than computers, you are probably in the wrong
industry :-)

> so I'm always trying to check up on what I
> think is going on... this is doubly true when I'm using new (for me)
> software like Junit.
>
> How do you Junit veterans assure yourself that a test is
> actually running and doing what it should be doing?

Heavy doses of alcohol do wonder for me :-)

More seriously, the HTML (or wherever you generate them) reports will help
you make sure your tests pass, and if you are not quite sure of yourself,
some redundancy in your tests doesn't hurt either (testing the same feature
twice in slightly modified ways in two different places).

But at some point, you really have to trust that your code is really being
executed and it takes a little leap of faith to get there (especially when
you are testing a testing framework with itself, which was the case in the
early days of TestNG :-)).
